title: 112_hr5858
content: The "Health Savings Accounts Improvements Act of 2012" includes provisions such as a Saver's credit for contributions to health savings accounts, a special rule for certain medical expenses, allowing both spouses to make catch-up contributions, eligibility for veterans benefits, and early retirees' distributions for health coverage. The "Health Savings Accounts Improvements Act of 2012" includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding qualified HSA contributions, allowing deductions for contributions to health savings accounts made by taxpayers or their employers. The taxpayer can elect to contribute to a cafeteria plan under section 125(d) without it being included in their gross income. Reporting of HSA elective contributions is amended to include amounts contributed under a cafeteria plan. Conforming amendments are made to section 25B(d)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. The aggregate retirement savings and HSA contributions shall be reduced by distributions received during the testing period. Special rule for certain medical expenses incurred before establishment of account. The amendment allows for the establishment of a health savings account within 60 days of coverage under a high deductible health plan, treating the account as if it was established on the date coverage began. This change applies to coverage starting after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Allow both spouses to make catch-up contributions to the same health savings account. SEC. 4 amends section 223(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow married individuals with family coverage under a high deductible health plan to combine their coverage for the purpose of contribution limitations. SEC. 4 of the Internal Revenue Code allows married individuals with family coverage under a high deductible health plan to combine their coverage for contribution limitations. The limitation on contributions is reduced by the aggregate amount paid to Archer MSAs of the spouses for the taxable year and divided equally between them unless agreed otherwise. If both spouses are over 55, the limitation subject to division includes additional contribution amounts. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. Individuals eligible for veterans benefits for a service-connected disability will not lose eligibility for certain tax benefits if they receive hospital care or medical services from the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. This amendment applies to months starting after December 31, 2012. SEC. 6. Distributions by certain early retirees for health coverage treated as qualified medical expense. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows early retirees aged 55 and above to use distributions for health coverage as qualified medical expenses. Effective from January 1, 2013.
